newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico to stay out of ACPC coffee export scheme.
newsitem.headline: Mexico to stay out of ACPC coffee export scheme.

text.p: Mexico reaffirmed Friday that it has no intention of joining the coffee export quota scheme of the Association of Coffee Producing Countries (ACPC), the executive director of the Mexican Coffee Council said.
"We have told them (the ACPC) that we are not going to form part of the group" Ruben Castillo told Reuters in an interview.

The Mexican Coffee Council is the private and public sector umbrella group for the coffee industry in Mexico. Agriculture Minister Francisco Labastida Ochoa is the council's figurehead president. Castillo is the day-to-day head of the group
ACPC nations, led by Brazil and Colombia, have been pushing Mexico to join the export limit scheme which bids to push up world prices by limiting supplies to consumer nations.
Mexico and Guatemala were earmarked as two nations the ACPC wanted to come into the fold. Guatemala said earlier Friday they would not attend the ACPC gathering.

Mexico has always steered clear of quota schemes, claiming its free trade pact with the United States and Canada -- the North American Free Trade Agreement -- prevents it from joining because it would go against government free market ideals.
Castillo added he would not attend next week's coffee gatherings in London but said Mexican delegations would be formed from representatives from the Mexican Embassy in London.
Both the ACPC and the International Coffee Organisation hold meetings in the British capital next week.
--Chris Aspin, Mexico City newsroom (525) 7289530. E-mail at chris.aspin@reuters.com
